title: Envy (apple)
text:
Envy is a trademarked brand of the Scilate <a href="apple">apple</a> variety. Scilate is the result of a cross between Royal <a href="Gala%20%28apple%29">Gala</a> and <a href="Braeburn">Braeburn</a>. It was developed in <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a> by <a href="HortResearch">HortResearch</a>, submitted for a patent in 2008 and patented in 2009.
The Envy apple is a mostly red with yellow specks. The peel is fairly thick and tough. The flesh is pale yellow. It is a sweet apple with low acid and a slightly flowery taste. 
Distribution of the Envy apple in North America began in 2009 through the <a href="Oppenheimer%20Group">Oppenheimer Group</a>, and <a href="ENZA">ENZA</a> (The New Zealand Apple and Pear Marketing Board); they began small commercial volumes in 2012 in <a href="Washington%20%28state%29">Washington state</a>. The first fruit surpassed 100,000 cartons for production in 2014. The companies anticipate harvesting 2 million cartons of the fruit by 2020.
Envy apples are being grown under license in New Zealand, Australia, Washington (U.S. state) and <a href="Chile">Chile</a>. Field tests are also being done in the UK, France, and with organic cultivation in Italy.
